title: Pablo López on point as Twins earn series split with Rays
text:
Pablo López on point as Twins earn series split with Rays
Edouard Julien and Matt Wallner homered for the offense as the Twins split a four-game series with a 4-3 victory
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Fresh off an ugly defensive game on Wednesday, and digesting tough injury news about Byron Buxton, who will be delayed in his return, and Max Kepler, who landed on the injured list, the Twins needed someone who could send them to Kansas City for a pivotal series against the Royals with some optimism.
And who better than Pablo López?
ADVERTISEMENT
López has looked every bit the ace in the second half of the season and on Thursday, he helped lead the Twins to a 4-3 win over the Tampa Bay Rays in the series finale at Tropicana Field.
“The team picked me up plenty of times in the first half when I wasn’t at my best or my sharpest,” López said. “It’s one of those things that you have to take it personal. We were down in the series and I knew I had an opportunity to come out here and do it for my guys, for my teammates.”
His 23⅓-scoreless innings streak was broken in the third inning when he allowed a two-run single to top prospect Junior Caminero, but the right-hander featured some of his best stuff as the Twins (76-64) salvaged a split of the four-game series.
López threw three different pitches above 98 mph, including one at 98.6 — the hardest pitch of his career. And his sweeper had a 70 percent whiff rate, accounting for seven of the 18 swinging strikes he racked up in the game.
ADVERTISEMENT
“As well as he’s been throwing the ball, this may have been as good of a day with some of his best stuff we’ve seen literally in two years,” bench coach Jayce Tingler said.
He gave up just one other run in the game, in the seventh inning when Yandy Díaz doubled to right. Matt Wallner tracked down the ball and his momentum took him tumbling over the outfield wall.
A lengthy rules review followed as the umpires figured out which base to place Díaz on. More than 10 minutes had passed, likely leading to the of López’s day as Griffin Jax was summoned to finish off the seventh inning.
ADVERTISEMENT
López said he was a little frustrated because one of the few fastballs he yanked in the game went for a double and then the delay took much longer than he expected.
“I was hoping to stay in the game after that, just to give me an opportunity to end on a better note by getting that last out,” López said. “But didn’t win that conversation. The best reliever in baseball came to get that last out.”
Though he didn’t get that final 21st out that he was hoping for, it was yet again another promising start from López when his team needed him the most.
And it comes as no surprise to those around him.
ADVERTISEMENT
“We know how hard he works. We know how good his stuff is. It felt like it was just a tick off (earlier this season). I think we knew this was coming,” catcher Ryan Jeffers said. “He’s our ace. He’s been our ace. He’s one of the top pitchers in all of baseball and he’s showing that now.”
The Twins’ top starter pitched with the lead for much of the day as Edouard Julien stepped up offensively and hit his first major league home run since April 25 in the second inning, a three-run shot off Rays (69-71) starter Taj Bradley on a pitch left over the heart of the plate. Wallner hit a solo homer an inning later for a 4-0 lead the Rays were unable to overcome.
With the split, the injury-depleted Twins now travel to Kansas City, to face the Royals, on whom they have a half game advantage in the American League Central. Both teams are currently positioned to win a Wild Card berth.
ADVERTISEMENT
“We all have a job to try to help the team win,” Julien said. “If everybody does that, I think we’re going to win some games. It (doesn’t) matter who it is. It’s the next man up.”
